title: Portrait of a Knight of Malta
text:
Portrait of a Knight of Malta is a c.1515 oil on canvas painting by <a href="Titian">Titian</a> of a <a href="knight">knight</a> belonging to the <a href="Knights%20Hospitaller">Order of Malta</a>. It is now in the <a href="Uffizi">Uffizi</a> in Florence. The last bead of the <a href="rosary">rosary</a> held by the knight bears the number XXXV (35), showing the subject's age at the time of the portrait. W.F. Dickes. argued that he was <a href="Stefano%20Colonna%20di%20Palestrina">Stefano Colonna</a>, the condottiero who led the republican resistance during the siege of Florence. cited in 
Thanks to <a href="Paolo%20del%20Sera">Paolo del Sera</a>, his agent in Venice, cardinal <a href="Leopoldo%20de%27%20Medici">Leopoldo de' Medici</a> acquired several works by the Venetian school for his collection, which later became part of the Uffizi. "Portrait" was one of these works, costing 300 <a href="piastre">piastre</a>s, showing it was already considered to be an autograph work. It was exhibited in the <a href="Tribuna%20%28Uffizi%29">Tribuna</a> in 1677 and attributed to <a href="Giorgione">Giorgione</a> in 1709, as shown on a label on the back of the painting. It was then moved to the <a href="villa%20di%20Poggio%20a%20Caiano">villa di Poggio a Caiano</a>. After several subsequent moves, in <a href="1798">1798</a> it finally arrived back Uffizi.
Oxidisation in the paint in the 19th century made attribution difficult. <a href="Joseph%20Archer%20Crowe">Joseph Archer Crowe</a>, <a href="Cavalcaselle">Cavalcaselle</a> and <a href="Giovanni%20Morelli%20%28art%20historian%29">Giovanni Morelli</a> could not decide on the work's artist, Otto Mündler (1869) argued it was by <a href="Pietro%20della%20Vecchia">Pietro della Vecchia</a> and <a href="Roberto%20Longhi">Roberto Longhi</a> that it was by <a href="Paris%20Bordone">Paris Bordone</a> - other critics shifted between <a href="Giorgione">Giorgione</a> and Titian as the artist. Stefano Scarpelli restored it in 1998, enabling it to be identified as an early Titian still with heavy influences from Giorgione.
